text:
Edward, I understand what you mean! Bad usability / presentation is what is driving many of us to try to make things better. What I've described above is not the end goal, it's just the required mechanism to create a tool that can customize itself to *become* whatever is the best tool or representation for a whatever you want to use it for.

The idea is not for something Lispy to be what's actually presented. That's just a good structure for storing and data representation. I actually think if it more like JSON.

The idea is to be able to say "for this given code or data, draw this (perhaps very different) UI".

The idea is to be able to say "for this given code or data, draw this (perhaps very different) UI".

text: <@UH84GQ3CZ> - I got part way through responding about my project(s) before the conversation went elsewhere. I've now edited my original comment (above) with my full reply.

elements.text: - I got part way through responding about my project(s) before the conversation went elsewhere. I've now edited my original comment (above) with my full reply.

text: One major difference between my two projects is that the second (Interact) keeps a history: every edit or manipulation is saved as an "action". Any change causes everything to be recomputed by reapplying all actions in order. Code is made of actions, so there is zero difference between user interaction and "programming", and it's like the program is in constant debug-mode as you edit it.
